docs.lead_paragraph: UROWSKY--Richard J. The lawyers and staff of Sullivan & Cromwell LLP mourn the loss of our beloved partner Richard J. Urowsky. Richard died at New York Presbyterian Hospital on January 14, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. He was 67 years old. We regret that Richard was taken from us so soon. Richard is survived by his sister, Ellen, brother-in-law Allen, nephews Andrew and Jonathan, cousins Edward, Norma, Peter and Robert, and many close friends and family. Richard was raised in the Bronx, and graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in 1963. He then attended Yale College, where he was a member of the Elihu Senior Society, secretary of the Aurelian Honor Society, a member of the Elizabethan Club, and an editorial assistant for The Review of Metaphysics. Richard was a philosopher from an early age. After eight straight semesters on the Dean's List and his election to Phi Beta Kappa, Richard graduated from Yale with high honors in 1967. He studied with the great legal philosopher H.L.A. Hart at New College in Oxford University as the C.P. Howland Fellow, receiving a degree in Political Theory and Legal Philosophy. Richard also was a graduate of Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale Law Journal. Following law school, Richard was a law clerk for Justice Stanley Reed of the US Supreme Court. During his tenure at the Court, Richard also spent time working in the chambers of Chief Justice Warren Burger and Justices Potter Stewart and Byron White. Richard returned to New York to begin the private practice of law in 1973. He spent his entire legal career at Sullivan & Cromwell, starting as an associate in the litigation department, and becoming a partner of the firm in 1980. He represented a wide range of clients, from financial services firms to automobile manufacturers to commercial printing companies. Whether the case was large or small, Richard always brought his incisive approach to legal issues to bear. Richard was perhaps best known for leading the defense of Microsoft in several antitrust cases brought against the company during the 1990s by the US government. His command of the enormous factual record developed during a six-month trial and his mastery of a wide range of complex legal subjects during a multi-day oral argument before the en banc US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in February 2001 was a sight to behold. Richard was a brilliant lawyer, one who combined a rigorous analytical mind with a sparkling wit. Richard was also a wonderful teacher who was very generous with his time in mentoring younger lawyers. We all learned a lot from him. We were lucky to have had Richard as a friend and colleague for the last 40 years. He was, as one loyal client said upon hearing of his death, "a force of nature and a very good human being." He made us proud of his many accomplishments, but he also made us laugh. We will miss his great intelligence and his subversive sense of humor in equal measure.

docs.lead_paragraph: UROWSKY--Richard J. The lawyers and staff of Sullivan & Cromwell LLP mourn the loss of our beloved partner Richard J. Urowsky. Richard died at New York Presbyterian Hospital on January 14, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. He was 67 years old. We regret that Richard was taken from us so soon. Richard is survived by his sister, Ellen, brother-in-law Allen, nephews Andrew and Jonathan, cousins Edward, Norma, Peter and Robert, and many close friends and family. Richard was raised in the Bronx, and graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in 1963. He then attended Yale College, where he was a member of the Elihu Senior Society, secretary of the Aurelian Honor Society, a member of the Elizabethan Club, and an editorial assistant for The Review of Metaphysics. Richard was a philosopher from an early age. After eight straight semesters on the Dean's List and his election to Phi Beta Kappa, Richard graduated from Yale with high honors in 1967. He studied with the great legal philosopher H.L.A. Hart at New College in Oxford University as the C.P. Howland Fellow, receiving a degree in Political Theory and Legal Philosophy. Richard also was a graduate of Yale Law School, where he was an editor of the Yale Law Journal. Following law school, Richard was a law clerk for Justice Stanley Reed of the US Supreme Court. During his tenure at the Court, Richard also spent time working in the chambers of Chief Justice Warren Burger and Justices Potter Stewart and Byron White. Richard returned to New York to begin the private practice of law in 1973. He spent his entire legal career at Sullivan & Cromwell, starting as an associate in the litigation department, and becoming a partner of the firm in 1980. He represented a wide range of clients, from financial services firms to automobile manufacturers to commercial printing companies. Whether the case was large or small, Richard always brought his incisive approach to legal issues to bear. Richard was perhaps best known for leading the defense of Microsoft in several antitrust cases brought against the company during the 1990s by the US government. His command of the enormous factual record developed during a six-month trial and his mastery of a wide range of complex legal subjects during a multi-day oral argument before the en banc US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in February 2001 was a sight to behold. Richard was a brilliant lawyer, one who combined a rigorous analytical mind with a sparkling wit. Richard was also a wonderful teacher who was very generous with his time in mentoring younger lawyers. We all learned a lot from him. We were lucky to have had Richard as a friend and colleague for the last 40 years. He was, as one loyal client said upon hearing of his death, "a force of nature and a very good human being." He made us proud of his many accomplishments, but he also made us laugh. We will miss his great intelligence and his subversive sense of humor in equal measure.

docs.lead_paragraph: BURROUGHS--Davis "Chip" III, Davis "Chip" Burroughs III, Asbury Park resident and renowned chef, dies at 63. Chip passed away on August 9, 2014 while surrounded by family at the Jersey Shore University Medical Center in Neptune, NJ. "Chip" is survived by his life partner Betsy Old; his daughter Elizabeth B. Doerr; son Davis C. Burroughs IV; sister Bunny Krueger and her son Jamie Jordan; brother Peter Burroughs and his son Jeffrey Burroughs and daughter Lauren Burroughs; son-in-law Michael Doerr; step-son Forrest R. Old III and his fiance Lauren Sewell; and his beloved cat, Leroy. Chip's parents, Davis C. Burroughs Jr. and Jean K. Weidlein preceded him in death. In addition to his culinary degree, Chip earned a BA from Ohio Wesleyan University in Technical Theatre and a BA from Housatonic College in Computer Science. He was a Certified Microsoft Engineer. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, Chip was unusually gifted and multi-talented. Known for his spirited wit, ebullience, generosity, kindness and expansive creativity, Chip was a true Renaissance man. Accomplished in diverse fields, his passion and renown was as an Executive Chef. He trained at the Culinary Institute of America, and owned a successful catering company in Fairfield, CT for 20+ years. In 2011, Chip and Betsy founded The Asbury Ocean Beach Inn, an award-winning bed and breakfast in Asbury Park, NJ. Chip was a member of the Rotary Club of Asbury Park and donated his services to numerous charitable events. Chip's legacy includes memories of him delivering culinary masterpieces to his friends when testing new recipes. A legendary and colorful personality, Chip was a devoted and beloved father, husband and friend who will remain in hearts forever. To celebrate Chip's love of the sea, a memorial service will be held on Asbury Park Beach S on Saturday, August 16 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, and to honor Chip's love of animals, the family requests donations be made to: Rescue Ridge P.O. Box 223 Spring Lake, NJ 07762 www.rescueridge.com.

docs.lead_paragraph: MOLLMAN--John Peter, died on July 30, 2014, at his home in Carmel, CA. Peter is survived by his wife Carol of 16 years, his daughter Sarah Underhill (Robert) of Bronx- ville, NY; son Eric (Mary) of Winnetka, IL, and stepson David (Janet) Moga of San Mateo, CA, and by eight grandchildren: Molly and Sam Underhill; Maddy, Tim, Annie, and Ellie Mollman; and Zoe and Ava Moga. His marriage to Jane Kendall Mollman, in 1953, ended in divorce. Peter was born on February 8, 1931, in Belleville, IL. He earned his MA from Washington University in St. Louis in 1952. He spent his professional life in publishing in New York at Harper & Row and Random House, Inc., World Book in Chicago, and finally Microsoft in Seattle. In retirement, he channeled his immense creative energy into the design and development of an Italian food website: www.classicpasta.com. As Peter himself described it, one of the most delightful and memorable moments in his long publishing career was meeting Marcella and Victor Hazan and his subsequent role in the development of The Classic Italian Cookbook. Peter had signed up for an Italian cooking class with the Hazans in New York, in search of the food he had come to love in his travels; the authenticity of their food was nowhere to be found in American cookbooks at the time. A friendship and partnership were born, and the first edition of this seminal work on Northern Italian cooking was published by Peter at Harper's Magazine Press in 1973. His passions included art, music, travel, food and wine, and all things Italian, and his volunteer commitments reflected these interests. Peter had an exceptional zest for life, and his signature laugh was contagious. A celebration of his life will take place at his home in Carmel. Donations in Peter's honor may be made to the Carmel Public Library Foundation, PO Box 2042, Carmel, CA 93921-2042, (831)624-2881, http://carmelpubliclibrary foundation.org; or to Chamber Music Monterey Bay, PO Box 221458, Carmel, CA 93922, www.chambermusicmontereybay.org

docs.abstract: Some scientists are calling for more research into geoengineering techniques, which could be used to slow global warming; one approach is to remove some carbon dioxide from atmosphere so it would trap less energy; another is to make atmosphere more reflective by adding particles or altering clouds, so less heat is trapped; critics warn that effects of geoengineering are unknown and could have unequal effects around the world.
